overview: The purpose of this measure is to require pharmacy technicians to be registered with the Board of Pharmacy by January 1, 2026. [4] This measure has been amended by adding a definition of 'auxiliary pharmacy personnel' for personnel that may be at the pharmacy, but whose duties are clerical in nature. [4] The amendments also clarify the duties of registered pharmacy technicians and what constitutes supervision by a registered pharmacist. [4]
policy_impact: This measure was amended by adding a definition of 'auxiliary pharmacy personnel' for personnel whose duties are clerical in nature and excluding these individuals from the definition of 'pharmacy technician'. [4] The bill now includes a new definition for 'Registered pharmacy technician' as a person, exclusive of pharmacy interns and auxiliary pharmacy personnel, who may perform filling, packaging, manipulative, repetitive, or other nondiscretionary tasks under supervision. [3] 'Supervision' is defined as the direction and oversight of a registered pharmacy technician or pharmacy intern by a physically present, responsible registered pharmacist. [3]
six_year_fiscal_implications: This Act shall take effect on July 1, 3000. [3] The Committee has amended this measure by changing the effective date to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion. [4] Consequently, there are no fiscal implications within the six-year fiscal planning period. [3]
operating_revenue_impact: Because the Act's effective date is July 1, 3000, there will be no impact on operating revenues in the foreseeable future. [3]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: As this Act shall take effect on July 1, 3000, there are no fiscal implications for the state after the initial six-year period. [3]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The measure has been amended to add a definition of 'auxiliary pharmacy personnel' to distinguish employees with clerical duties from pharmacy technicians. [4] The duties for registered pharmacy technicians and the definition of 'supervision' have been clarified. [4] The most significant change is that the effective date has been amended to July 1, 3000, which postpones all fiscal impacts of the bill indefinitely. [3] [4]
